image.altText: A montage of four different images showing two people in sunglasses and balaclavas, a meth pipe and a bag of white crystals

props.synopsis: Australians are among the biggest users of ice in the world. Four Corners investigates where some of that crystal meth is coming from, and who's behind it.

title.children: People in the crystal meth underworld have a code of silence. Here it gets broken

image.altText: julie inman grant speaks at a press conference

props.synopsis: The eSafety commissioner has been granted a two-day legal injunction to compel social media platform X to hide posts that include graphic footage relating to the Wakeley stabbing.

title.children: eSafety commissioner wins two-day injunction against X over Wakeley church stabbing footage

image.altText: A man with short grey hair and glasses wearing a suit, sitting behind a microphone icking up a piece of paper as he speaks

props.synopsis: The former home affairs secretary had a decorated career in the public service before a series of leaked messages cost him his job. He now admits he has no one to blame but himself.

title.children: Former home affairs boss Pezzullo issues warning on China, admits his mistakes cost him his job

image.altText: a grey Brahman cow looking at the camera, with other cattle behind.

props.synopsis: Investigations into the deaths of about 150 Northern Territory cattle suggest the likely cause was a parasitic disease called coccidiosis.

title.children: 'Strong evidence' suggests parasitic disease killed 150 NT cattle

image.altText: a bald man with facial hair wearing glasses

props.synopsis: NT Police Constable James Kirstenfeldt — who was deployed to Yuendumu in 2019 when Kumanjayi Walker was shot — has been charged with drink-driving and going armed in public after an incident in Darwin over the weekend.

title.children: NT Police constable charged with going armed in public while off duty

image.altText: a ship next to a damaged wharf.

props.synopsis: For two days in March the MV Anikitos was smashed into the wharf by cyclonic winds and 4-metre-high seas, rendering it unusable. Now South32 confirms there would be no manganese exports until early 2025.

title.children: No exports from major NT mine for up to 12 months after cyclone damage

image.altText: A Chinese flag is held up poolside by unidentifiable members of Team China

props.synopsis: The World Anti-Doping Agency says it stands firmly by its investigation into the case of 23 Chinese swimmers who tested positive to the same banned substance, as questions are raised over claims of food contamination.

title.children: WADA accepts Chinese swimmers tested positive to banned substance due to contaminated kitchen

image.altText: Elon Musk holds both hands out in front of him while contorting his mouth into a horrified expression

props.synopsis: In this week's round-up of the best, worst and strangest in tech news, Elon Musk chucks a Bart Simpson in — figuratively — mooning the Australian government, and Meta's new AI claims it has a child.

title.children: The unintended consequences of Elon Musk's Bart Simpson moment and surprising bugs in Meta's new AI chatbot

image.altText: Man woman and 23-year-old daughter sit outside on the grass. their small brown dog at their feet

props.synopsis: Anna Coutts-Trotter was a teenager doing well at school, living at home with supportive parents Tanya Plibersek and Michael Coutts-Trotter. But she was being abused by her then-boyfriend.

title.children: 'I wanted to kill him for hurting my child': Tanya Plibersek reveals daughter's fight for survivors

image.altText: Aerial view of flooded buildings.

props.synopsis: Floods have swamped a handful of cities in southern China following record-breaking rains, sparking worries about the region's defences against bigger deluges induced by extreme weather events.

title.children: Floods swamp southern China, fears for future of 'world's factory floor'

image.altText: Two young children sitting on a rock, surrounded by structures made of scrap metal

props.synopsis: World leaders have fought this Israeli "doomsday" settlement plan in the West Bank for decades. But now it's just "two pen strokes" away, and some are worried the war in Gaza could change everything.

title.children: Why Israel's 'doomsday' settlement is just 'two pen strokes' away

image.altText: Aharon Haliva

props.synopsis: The head of Israeli military intelligence, who last year accepted responsibility for the failures that allowed the Hamas-led attack on Israel on October 7, has resigned, the military says.

title.children: 'I have carried that black day with me ever since': Israeli military intelligence chief resigns over October 7 attack

image.altText: A man wearing football clothes

props.synopsis: West Adelaide footballer Sam May, 24, remains at the Royal Adelaide Hospital after an incident at Port Lincoln at the weekend. SA Police said emergency services were called to the Pier Hotel on Sunday morning after reports a man had fallen through the roof.

title.children: 'Sammy is the light of our lives': Footballer in hospital after incident at Port Lincoln hotel

image.altText: Johnathon Bush leans forward with his arms crossed over in front of one of his artworks.

props.synopsis: Johnathon "World Peace" Bush is the latest in a long line of remote Indigenous artists to have gained global recognition by telling stories to, and finding a value with, international audiences and buyers.

title.children: From a tiny community, Johnathan is a voice to the rest of the world

image.altText: A man standing in a park

props.synopsis: The identity of Victorian man Steven Leslie Hainsworth — who is charged with murdering three South Australians between 1998 and 2011 — can be revealed for the first time.

title.children: Identity of alleged Victorian serial killer revealed after Supreme Court lifts suppression order

image.altText: taylor tortured poets

props.synopsis: Taylor Swift commands the world's attention yet again with her new album The Tortured Poets Department. We unpack the best moments and greatest disappointments of this two-hour-long emotional rollercoaster.

title.children: Is The Tortured Poets Department a sign of genius, or does Taylor Swift need an editor?

image.altText: SLS beach report advising against swimming with a crocodile sign

props.synopsis: Two problem crocodiles have been targeted for removal by rangers after one came within "inches" of a marina houseboat resident and two canoeists spotted another while training.

title.children: Houseboat resident's crocodile encounter among multiple weekend sightings putting Far North Queenslanders on alert

image.altText: A small snake lifting its head in a snap lock plastic lunch container

props.synopsis: Hospital staff came face-to-face with one of the world's most deadly snakes after a patient brought it to the emergency department in a snap-lock lunch container.

title.children: Venomous snake brought into hospital in lunchbox prompts plea from doctors — 'please don't do this'

image.altText: A man holding a microphone on a stage

props.synopsis: The US comedian said a seven-month-old baby was disrupting his performance at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival.

title.children: Comedian Arj Barker responds after asking mother and baby to leave Melbourne show

image.altText: A composite image of a woman in a black hoodie, a loveheart-shaped pin of two boys, and a third boy in school uniform

props.synopsis: Dean Cluney and Tyrone Gardner were sentenced after pleading guilty to breaking into a home, then intimidating two female occupants before crash that killed Tania Murphy, her sons and a nephew at Yanco.

title.children: Pair get prison time for offences in lead up to crash that killed woman and three children

image.altText: road 3

props.synopsis: A man has been fatally shot by police after being intercepted in a stolen car and pulling a gun on officers on the Bruce Highway at a rest area at Colosseum, south of Gladstone.

title.children: Armed man shot dead by police who intercepted stolen car on Bruce Highway

image.altText: Patricia Santiago, a young woman of Filipino appearance, wears high-visibility clothes and drives a tram

props.synopsis: When Patricia's father suggested she drive a tram, she was a "corporate girl". Now she’s embraced having a route of her own.

title.children: Letting go of her 'status title' gave Patricia financial stability

image.altText: Woman in dayglow smiles at camera

props.synopsis: Young people are heading to the mines for higher-paid work and a better lifestyle as the cost of living bites and makes saving a distant dream for many.

title.children: Young people are choosing high-paying mining jobs to set themselves up amid cost of living crisis

image.altText: Woolworths CBD

props.synopsis: Woolworths NZ has seen a 75 per cent increase in physical assaults, in stores in the last three years.

title.children: Woolworths NZ staff to wear body cameras to protect them against customer abuse

image.altText: Tight shot of Andrews. she is right of frame mid speech

props.synopsis: The former Coalition cabinet minister believes "constant criticism and negativity" directed at those in political roles put women off agreeing to run for preselection in her long-held Gold Coast seat.

title.children: Retiring MP Karen Andrews says she couldn't convince any women in her party to contest safe seat

image.altText: Two anonymous policemen walk into a Canberra restaurant

props.synopsis: Mohammed Al Mofathel pleaded guilty to six charges in the ACT Supreme Court over the drug and money laundering scheme run out of a prestige Canberra restaurant.

title.children: A Lamborghini, a hatted restaurant, drugs and cash — ring-leader of Canberra criminal scheme jailed

image.altText: Sir Andrew Davis conducts in white tie with his eyes closed and rapt expression.

props.synopsis: Sir Andrew Davis made a significant impact on cultural life in Australia during his tenure as Chief Conductor of the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra from 2013 to 2019.

title.children: A 'generosity of spirit': Sir Andrew Davis, former Melbourne Symphony Chief Conductor, has died

image.altText: Anonymised pic of a doctor's hands at a desk holding a stethoscope

props.synopsis: Doctors warn the government's $3.5 billion investment to make visiting GPs more affordable is being pocketed by states that changed their payroll tax rules, leaving little room to lift bulk billing rates.

title.children: 'I can't afford to bulk bill people': GPs say state taxes are taking Medicare funding from them

image.altText: A ukraine flag and us flag in front of the capitol building.

props.synopsis: The Kremlin warned that passage of the bill would "further ruin" Ukraine and cause more deaths.

title.children: Ukraine expresses relief over US aid package approval as Russia issues a furious warning

image.altText: A sketch of Erin Patterson wearing a blue jumper and thin framed black glasses with her hair tied back.

props.synopsis: Erin Patterson's lawyers tell a regional Victorian court they are prepared to wait until next year for the case to progress to a committal hearing, despite an offer from the magistrate to have the matter fast-tracked to a Supreme Court trial.

title.children: Erin Patterson, accused of killing three people with mushrooms, faces Victorian court

image.altText: On a TV set, a young girl is strapped to a chair. Her nose is blleding, and three people look on concerned.

props.synopsis: Australian brothers Colin and Cameron Cairnes have made waves with their third film, a found-footage horror starring David Dastmalchian.

title.children: Late Night with the Devil invites a demon onto a 70s talk show, with disastrous consequences

image.altText: Kevin Bacon laughs wiht students in front of lockers

props.synopsis: Bacon danced his way to a stage on a Payson High School athletic field on Saturday to greet students before what likely was the final prom held at the school.

title.children: Kevin Bacon returns to Footloose high school before it is torn down

image.altText: Older man with cap worn backwards and loud patterned shirt in front of Gilligan's sign

props.synopsis: David Byrne is a self-described "73-year-old white guy" and "major nightclub dancer". His journey to becoming the local councillor of a far-flung Aboriginal community is as eventful as his first trip there.

title.children: Aboriginal community elects avid nightclub dancing 'white guy' as local councillor
